-zXuKlfL4nrwqpdns-SexQ.text: Promise me you will go to this place when you are in Singapore. As a super fan of roasted meat, I tried many places in Australia, China, Honking, Singapore, US etc. - this is simply that BEST of the best I've ever had. The soup is very nice too, and you get to eat some vegetables - so your mom will be happy. Not sure if there;s any public transportation to get there. We came by uber all the time and it worked fine. Avoid peak hours such us lunch hours for a better eating experience if you can.

dk15wVRJvQuOWHTM4X0M9g.text: The char siew was really really good!I came here not knowing what to expect. I have heard the standard has dropped ever since this place (recipe and all) has been sold and the meat are mostly cooked in a central kitchen. It was not very crowded when I was here after the peak lunch crowd. I forgot what they were famous for (duck? roast pork or char siew?) and just ordered the char siew and roast pork rice ($5) and it came quickly. It was a generous serving of white rice (more than I could finish) with gravy over it. The roast pork was good, with delightfully crispy skin. The meat could be softer though.The char siew was a surprise. The chunky slices were tender and moist with fatty bits at the bottom and sweetly charred on the outside. It was definitely the highlight and I could not remember having something like this anywhere else. So if you can only have one meat, just remember it is the CHAR SIEW which is the must order dish. The prices are similar to food court though the quality is way better at those nondescript run of the mill stalls.

photos.caption: Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Char Siew and roast pork rice $5
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore

efXFMTRbL7HL5CyyDc11yA.text: If you're looking for char siew that rocks your world, Kay Lee is the joint.I've had roast pork (8/10), roast duck (7/10), and char siew (10/10), and I just wish I could eat char siew, and nothing but char siew. It is wonderfully fatty, charred, and sweet. You eat it with rice and the sweet sauce that comes with it. I am convinced that bliss can indeed be bought (and eaten).The ambience of the place is un-airconditioned and no-frills, but the char siew makes do for all that is missing. You'd be a fool not to come here.Also, be warned, it wasn't cheap (three meats and rice with a refill of char siew plus drinks for 5, 70$), and it is perpetually crowded. We, a party of 5 came here at 1130 on a Friday for lunch, and golly, it was crowded by 12.

photos.caption: Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Not pretty, but this is a delicious mix of all the meats.
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Char siew.

LfP1z-lWgGDtNmQr0ps_vA.text: This place is already well known for the roasted meat. However compared to before the sale to AZTech for over $3 million, the standard of the roasted duck has dropped. The skin was not crispy and meat was dry. Some parts of the duck was nice so it seems like the cutter mixed both old and freshly made duck. The roasted pork was similar, some pieces of the pork skin was tough while some was crispy. Luckily the char siew was excellent just like before.The price has gone up, so stick to char siew.Was there on a weekday at 12.30pm, was surprised to be able to get a table (in fact several to choose from).

photos.caption: Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Not the owner cutting the meat now, because the previous owner is a million aire now
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Prices of the roasted dishes

lrV92po5QwkbsHfKmxWfBQ.text: Issit me or have prices gone through the roof!?? 3 meats with rice, old cucumber soup and a drink cost me $16 in a coffee shop setting by myself! Shocking. Sentosa prices!!

photos.caption: Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. I still love the Charsiew though.
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. This set cost me $16. 3 meats with rice, old cucumber soup and drink. I don't think I can afford your kopitiam prices anymore.

FpDVeSErn49pEF7BPydHOg.text: This is probably my favorite char siew in Singapore. Sweet and caramelized, fatty and totally black and charred! I've never bothered with the duck or roast pork cause my focus has always been the char siew!The watercress soup was good, flavorful without feeling like I was just drinking water and msg. So why is it not garnering 5*? As other reviews had already mentioned, parking is a nightmare. The prices are extremely high for the quantity you get and the attitudes of the aunties serving could be better. But hey! If I had one of the best char siews in Singapore, why would I care?!

photos.caption: Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Char siew
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Pig stomach soup
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Watercress soup

DTeIUh2crDt24X2pnVbpHQ.text: Here to try the 2.5million bucks duck rice hoping that the craze would already have died out but apparently not. The queue still snakes onto the road and there's a mix of army officers (no idea where they came from), office workers, old uncles and aunties and then us the odd young couple out.Then again, there is no discrimination when it comes to roast meat. How can anyone not like the crackling glossy skin of the duck or that buttery melt in your mouth fat that is so irresistible. A soup, 3 kinds of meat and 2 plates of rice cost us $27. Pricey but worth it. The duck may be a little dry but the char siew is to die for. The black caramelized dark sauce is great on the meats and on the rice as well. I absolutely dig the rice which is moist and really fluffy. You must order the char siew. It's fantabulous. The salted veg duck double boiled soup is also a great accompaniment to the meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. Storefront
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. The crowd
Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore. 3 roast meats

1a_cGkIV-9iyhwqDI2067g.text: Thick chunks of charsiew that just melt in the mouth. The best Part is that you can just go in anytime and get a plate full of yummy goodness. .they have roast pork too which I haven't tried as I am not a fan of roast pork but I be been told its equally delicious. For $5 a plate its a real steal!

eyIzwpP5JPnKzvAd-l9Cng.text: When there during Long some time ago the BBQ meat is more to the lean type and roast and sauce is good. Not the normal BBQ meat

IwMW7Np1l4ivE8dxRpFtzQ.text: Char siew - fantasticRoast pork belly - nice and crunchyRoast duck - ok okWatercress soup - niceParking - nightmare

photos.caption: Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore

Pt8UD21NaIThgT2YZnMoKQ.text: I first heard of Kay Lee from a Bloomberg article about how the owners are hoping to sell out for a few million SGD. I'm not sure it's worth quite that much, but their char siu is the best I've had since moving to Singapore, and come to think of it, may be better than any I've had in New York too.  Every piece is basically half-meat, half-fat, with this perfect burnt-but-not-overly-burnt crust that has just the right amount of salty, sweet glaze. It's ridiculously good. They have all the other usual roast meats and roast duck, but those all seemed fairly average to me.  You come for the char siu, and you eat an unhealthy, unreasonable amount of it. You'll pay a premium for this goodness, spending ~$15 per person, which is pretty pricey for a portion of roast meat and rice. But in addition to the char siu, you also get to see the owner's equally amazing perm as she chops away. She also tends to yell a lot at her staff, which is pretty entertaining as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint - Singapore, Singapore

nqSTe9_KlwqKc7Awz-E2eg.text: The food is nice, Charsiew just the way I like it, fatty and charred. Duck is good too. Unfortunately, the price is RIDICULOUS. if I could use a larger font size, I would. You will be paying restaurant prices for unknown amount of food. They do not tell you in advance how much it costs, just ask you how many portions. When the bill comes, be prepared to hit the roof! The service is also shit, but i guess its typical of hawkers who have a roaring business. Problem is, even the person taking your business (not the boss!) Has a shit attitude. The boss is the lady chopping the duck and meat.

R092snUw2EGgQ-WB3uOLNA.text: My family have been eating the roast meat from this place way before the 2.5 million hype. In fact, I think I stop going there as the line just get too crazy since. The char siew is delicious especially with the charred portions. I also love their roasted duck too with the plum sauce. The soups here are great too. I love the salted veg and duck soup. That's my all time favorite soup here. I find that the food here can be rather pricey. I realized it is cheaper to order per pax than order dishes to share.

RYUo2ZfCnfh2ywDiuquW4A.text: Is a recipe that's reputed to be worth S$2.5million or more really that good? Apparently so. If you love your char siew that is. The main attraction of Kay Lee Roasts is the three main offerings of Roast Duck, Roast Pork Belly(siew yoke) and Roast Pork (char siew).  Out of those three, only the char siew is consistent most of the times, with plenty of fats, and beautifully burnt and crisp bits found everywhere. The roast duck and roast pork belly are hit and miss really, since I've stopped ordering that when I'm there, just focusing on the char siew and their boiled soups as accompaniments instead. Getting there is relatively easy as its within walking distance of an MRT station, and you can always pop next door to get your 4D and ToTo after eating!

uEnp19se3dgkQdZhUVDfRw.text: Is Their Char Siew Shop Worth $3.5 Million? Singaporeans should be familiar with this story - The Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint is selling their business for $3.5 million - the amount includes $2 million for the recipe and $1.5 million for the shop space at Paya Lebar. Owners Betty Kong and husband have received bids of up to $3 million, but they will not accept a cent less. Their children did not want to take over the business.I wanted to wait till the hype dies down to find out if this is really worth $3.5 million. On a weekday afternoon at about 2.30pm, there were still about 6-7 people in the queue. The inside of the shop, which looked quite run-down and a blast from the 80s, was fully packed.I could not help noticing that despite being 6th in the queue - it took more than 20 minutes before we could even order our food, partly because people in the front were taking away packets. But more because the lady boss Betty, was cutting their meats really, really, really slow.The meats were indeed very delicious, my favourite being the char siew for being quite original in taste, and tender despite being lean. The roast pork belly is crispy and decent, while the roast duck is on the dry side - it needed the sauce. I actually thought the winning formula is in the combination of three sauces - the dark Hoisin sauce, brownish duck sauce and pinkish sweet chilli sauce that gets passed from table to table.

-BLU9jvWq858HRNvuYGHog.text: Best roasted pork in Singapore so far, imho. The bbq pork is a bit too sweet for me, losing the meaty taste. I also wanted to try the hakka salted chicken, but the lady told me that it wasn't available that day. I came just before the lunch crowd arrived, and boy the line had gone out the shop by the time I was done eating. Also, drink choice was kinda limited: ice lemon tea or barley.

4TlDIumTX0fZOsxQnk7PmA.text: If you want to relive your childhood memory of having charred fatty char siew rice then here is the place. But if u want to live longer then this is not a place for lean meats. Watercress and Salty Duck Soup is overrated. I have tasted better versions. Overpriced - 2 plates of roasted meats plus 2 soups cost SGD $18. Owner valued her roast meat business at 3.5 million. Overvalued and Overrated, no wonder up to now there are no suckers willing to pay that kind of price.

mVdH03rTXmovK0U_zvzp6A.text: Taste still as good. But disappointed with the charsiew that I got today is very fat. More than 50% is fatty meat
